    Using Portable Paths

    Matthew Strasiotto

    2020-01-28

    configuring-your-paths.Rmd

    A quick intro

    This implementation is supposed to provide portability, for people who want automating the processing of data that, for ethics reasons, must remain on a secure network share.

    The typical reliable solution for programmers needing access to this data would be to include it in their project repository, or by some other means so they could use relative path configuration to access their files.

    This solution makes use of two persistent configuration files so that R can find and load files: A local.yaml file, designed to never be checked into VCS, allowing a one-time set-up to find the root of the data directory. And a shared.yaml for project wide configuration of the contents within that directory.

    Let’s load our library before we get started

    library(portrpaths)

    The configration files

    Let’s have a quick look at what our configuration files might look like

    local_config <- tempfile()
file.copy("./local.yaml", local_config)

    The local config

    What about the local config?

    This is the file that designates just where to look for the root of the data-share. The rest is done by the first file we saw.

    This should never be checked into VCS.

    for (ln in readLines(local_config)) cat(ln, sep = "\n")
#> d_root: .PROJECT_ROOT
#> profiles:
#>   default: .PROJECT_ROOT

    On looking at that, we notice you may notice that this particular example designates d_root: .PROJECT_ROOT.

    .PROJECT_ROOT is a (the only) special case for designating this root, and will set the root to be the root of the current RStudio project and/or git repo

    Usually, you should specify an absolute path like - /Volumes/RDS-01/PRJ-STEMI/ (OSX)

    Using this config

    Now it’s time to use this configuration.

    Let’s load it up, and see what it looks like

    paths <- PortrPath$new(local_config_path = local_config)
#> 2020-01-28 16:56:55 INFO:PortrPath:Root in: .PROJECT_ROOT

print(paths)
#> Root: /Users/matthew/Documents/Hobby/portrpaths
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT

    Getting / Setting The Root

    Getting the value of the current root is simple

    root <- paths$root
print(root)
#> [1] "/Users/matthew/Documents/Hobby/portrpaths"

    Setting this value is equally simple

    paths$root <- "/project/STEMI"
#> 2020-01-28 16:56:55 INFO:PortrPath:Root in: /project/STEMI
#> Setting root to /project/STEMI

print(paths)
#> Root: /project/STEMI
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT

    Profiles

    Profiles allow us to quickly change between different roots

    paths
#> Root: /project/STEMI
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT

    Let’s add a profile for quickly swapping to a mounted data share

    paths$add_profile("hpc_root", "/project/STEMI")
paths
#> Root: /project/STEMI
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT
#>     hpc_root: /project/STEMI

    Now let’s swap back over to the default profile

    paths$profile <- "default"
#> Setting profile to default
#> 2020-01-28 16:56:55 INFO:PortrPath:Root in: .PROJECT_ROOT
#> Setting root to /Users/matthew/Documents/Hobby/portrpaths
paths
#> Root: /Users/matthew/Documents/Hobby/portrpaths
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT
#>     hpc_root: /project/STEMI

    We can swap back to the mounted share pretty easily:

    paths$profile <- "hpc_root"
#> Setting profile to hpc_root
#> 2020-01-28 16:56:55 INFO:PortrPath:Root in: /project/STEMI
#> Setting root to /project/STEMI
paths
#> Root: /project/STEMI
#> Profiles:
#>     default: .PROJECT_ROOT
#>     hpc_root: /project/STEMI
